rules.title: Detection of Phishing Activity via Office Processes Spawning Command Shells
rules.description: This rule detects potential phishing activity by identifying Office processes (such as WINWORD.EXE) spawning command shells (cmd.exe, powershell.exe), which could indicate malicious activity.
falsepositives: Legitimate automation or troubleshooting activities by users
Administrative tasks that involve spawning command shells from Office applications

rules.title: Detection of PowerShell Activity via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects PowerShell activity using natural language processing (NLP) pattern matching to identify potential malicious command execution
falsepositives: PowerShell scripts used by authorized tools or software

rules.title: Screen Capture Detection via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity by monitoring process creation events for known screen capture tools and techniques
falsepositives: Legitimate use of screen capture tools by administrators or users for documentation purposes
Gaming or video recording software that may use similar command lines or image paths

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process Detection
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via process creation events

rules.title: Detection: Process Injection
rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Application Layer Protocol
rules.description: Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects obfuscated files or information using NLP pattern matching and behavioral analysis

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
rules.description: Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) Abuse Detection
rules.description: Detects Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching, indicating potential WMI abuse techniques
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using wmic.exe
Scripted system monitoring or automation tools

rules.title: Detection: OS Credential Dumping
rules.description: Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Network Service Discovery
rules.description: Detects Network Service Discovery activity via process creation and command line analysis

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate archiving of files by users
System processes archiving data for backup purposes

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Detection
rules.description: Detects Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of schtasks.exe for scheduling backups or updates
Use of schtasks.exe by system or network service accounts for maintenance tasks

rules.title: Input Capture Detection via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Input Capture activity by analyzing process creation events for suspicious command line arguments and parent processes
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using powershell.exe or cmd.exe

rules.title: Remote Desktop Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Remote Desktop Protocol activity via process creation and network connection events

rules.title: User Execution: Malicious File
rules.description: Detects User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

attacks.description: Basic phishing attempt using PowerShell to prompt the user for credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to enter their credentials, simulating a phishing attempt.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo Please click this link: https://example.com > phishing.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attempt creating a text file with a suspicious link.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a text file named 'phishing.txt' containing a link, which could be used in a phishing email or message.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Form'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Enter your credentials:'; $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attempt using PowerShell to create a form that prompts the user for credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a form with a label asking the user to enter their credentials, simulating a sophisticated phishing attempt.

attacks.description: Create a file named phishing.txt with content that could be used in a phishing email or page.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing.txt is created in the current directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Send an email with a subject that could be used in a phishing campaign, using the content of the phishing.txt file created earlier.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is sent to the specified address with the subject 'Phishing Test' and the body containing the text from phishing.txt.

attacks.command: mkdir phishing_campaign; echo 'You have been phished' > phishing_campaign/readme.txt
attacks.description: Create a directory named phishing_campaign and inside it, create a file named readme.txt with deceptive content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named phishing_campaign is created, and inside it, a file named readme.txt is created with the specified content.

attacks.description: Execute a basic PowerShell command to list running processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes in the console.

attacks.description: An intermediate example that creates a file in the temp directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's temp directory with the content 'Test content'.

attacks.description: An advanced example that downloads a webpage using PowerShell, assuming internet access for demonstration purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content of http://example.com and saves it as example.html in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to get a list of running processes on the Linux system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute successfully and display a list of running processes.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory and writes 'Hello World!' to it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute successfully and create a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the contents 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress the test.txt file in the /tmp directory into a zip archive named test.zip, overwriting any existing file with the same name.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute successfully and create a zip archive named test.zip in the /tmp directory containing the test.txt file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $screen = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $bmp = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $screen.Width, $screen.Height; $gfx = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $gfx.CopyFromScreen($screen.Left, $screen.Top, 0, 0, $bmp.Size); $bmp.Save('%TEMP%\screenshot.png');"
attacks.description: Captures the screen using PowerShell and saves it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves a screenshot in the temp directory without any visible output.

attacks.description: Captures the screen using mspaint and saves it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens mspaint with the screenshot, allowing the user to save it manually.

attacks.description: Advanced screen capture using PowerShell, handling virtual screen dimensions and saving as PNG.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves an advanced screenshot in the temp directory, accounting for the virtual screen size.

attacks.description: Capture the screen after a 5-second delay and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen after a 5-second delay and save the screenshot to the current working directory.

attacks.description: Record the screen with a resolution of 1280x720, a framerate of 30, and save the output to a file named output.mp4
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen and save the output to the current working directory.

attacks.description: Record the screen with a resolution of 1920x1080, a framerate of 60, for a duration of 60 seconds, and save the output to a file named advanced_output.mp4
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen for 60 seconds and save the output to the current working directory.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service will be created

attacks.description: Start a system service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The system service will be started

attacks.description: Create a new system process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process will be created

attacks.description: Start the SSH service to create a new system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will start, creating a new system process.

attacks.description: Restart the Nginx service to modify an existing system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The Nginx service will restart, modifying the existing system process.

attacks.description: Edit the cron table to create a new system process at a scheduled time
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be edited, allowing for the creation of a new system process at a scheduled time.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using rundll32 to load user32.dll and execute MessageBeep, which is a simple, benign payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will produce a beep sound, indicating successful execution of the injected process.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using PowerShell to start a new cmd.exe process, which then executes a benign echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new command prompt window will appear, print 'Hello, World!', and then close.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern int MessageBeep(int uType);' -Name U32 -Namespace W; [W.U32]::MessageBeep(0)}"
attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to dynamically load user32.dll and invoke the MessageBeep function, demonstrating more complex process interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will produce a beep sound, similar to the basic example, but through more advanced process manipulation.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using gdb to allocate memory, copy shellcode, make the memory executable, and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command injects code into a running process with the given pid, demonstrating basic process injection capabilities

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using a gdb script to perform more complex memory operations and code execution
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates an intermediate level of process injection by utilizing a gdb script to allocate larger memory, copy more complex shellcode, make the memory executable, and execute it

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using a custom compiled program to handle the injection, potentially using more sophisticated techniques like hooking or API manipulation
attacks.expected_behavior: This command represents an advanced scenario where a custom program is compiled and used to inject code into a process, potentially leveraging more complex and powerful techniques

attacks.description: Start the telnet service to simulate command and control activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service will be started, allowing for potential command and control communications.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, simulating data exfiltration or communication
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a file from a URL, simulating command and control or data staging
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to listen on port 8080 using netcat, demonstrating the use of an application layer protocol for potential command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on port 8080, and any incoming connection can potentially be used for command and control, demonstrating application layer protocol usage.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to connect to a remote server on port 80, simulating command and control communication over an application layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command establishes a connection to the specified server on port 80, which could be used for command and control, illustrating the application layer protocol technique.

attacks.description: Advanced command using UDP to listen on port 8080, demonstrating another aspect of application layer protocol usage for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on UDP port 8080, allowing for potential command and control communication over UDP, an application layer protocol.

attacks.description: Add a new user using the net.exe command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user will be added to the system

attacks.description: Get a list of files on the public desktop using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of files on the public desktop will be displayed

attacks.description: Decode a base64 encoded file using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 encoded file will be decoded and saved as a new file

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Test Command'

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo "Hello $i"; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute a loop using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello 1' through 'Hello 5' to the console

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a delayed command in the background using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: After a 5-second delay, prints 'Delayed Test' to the console, demonstrating asynchronous command execution

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be encoded and saved as a new file

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated script using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will create a file with obfuscated content

attacks.description: Create a compressed archive with an obfuscated name using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The archive will be created with an obfuscated name

attacks.description: Basic example of creating an obfuscated script using base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: The obfuscated script will be executed without being detected

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using openssl to decode and execute the obfuscated script
attacks.expected_behavior: The obfuscated script will be executed without being detected

attacks.description: Advanced example of using python to decode and execute the obfuscated script
attacks.expected_behavior: The obfuscated script will be executed without being detected

attacks.description: Encode a test string to base64 to simulate data exfiltration preparation
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes a test string into base64, which could be a step in preparing data for exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.description: Use certutil to encode a file, simulating data preparation for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes a test file using certutil, which can be used to prepare data for exfiltration.

attacks.description: Create a file with test data and then 'exfiltrate' it by copying the content to another file, simulating data movement
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file with test data and then copies this data to another file, simulating the exfiltration of sensitive data.

attacks.description: Simulate exfiltrating data using netcat to a hypothetical C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the string 'Test exfiltration data' to the specified server and port, simulating data exfiltration.

attacks.description: Use curl to exfiltrate data by sending it as part of a POST request to a hypothetical C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the string 'Test exfiltration data' in the body of a POST request to the specified URL, simulating data exfiltration over HTTP.

attacks.description: Download a script from a hypothetical C2 server and execute it, simulating a more complex exfiltration scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from the specified URL and then executes it, demonstrating a potential method for exfiltrating data or executing further malicious commands.

attacks.description: Simulate adding a new user to exploit public-facing application vulnerabilities, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user is added to the system, simulating a potential exploit vector.

attacks.description: Download a file to simulate the exploitation process, using PowerShell for lack of a legacy binary alternative.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named exploit.txt is downloaded from the specified URI to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Use certutil to fetch a potentially malicious payload, simulating an exploit without executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file is fetched from the specified URL, simulating the download of a malicious payload without actual execution.

attacks.description: Basic attempt to exploit a public-facing web application using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to send a GET request to a hypothetical vulnerable application, potentially triggering an exploit.

attacks.description: Intermediate attempt using wget to post data to a potentially vulnerable application.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses wget to send a POST request with exploit data to the vulnerable application, simulating an exploitation attempt.

attacks.description: Advanced attempt using Python and the requests library to exploit a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command utilizes Python to send a POST request with exploit data to the vulnerable application, demonstrating a more sophisticated exploitation attempt.

attacks.description: Retrieve the operating system caption using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the operating system caption, demonstrating basic WMI query execution.

attacks.description: List all running processes briefly using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes with basic information, showcasing intermediate WMI usage.

attacks.description: Retrieve detailed operating system information using PowerShell's Get-WmiObject Cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns detailed information about the operating system, including version, build, and service pack details, demonstrating advanced WMI querying.

attacks.description: List all running processes using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list all running processes on the system.

attacks.description: Get CPU information using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display CPU information, such as the number of cores and the current clock speed.

attacks.description: Get OS information using wmic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display OS information, such as the version, build number, and service pack level.

attacks.description: Lists all stored credentials on the system, which can be used for credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials.

attacks.description: Exports the SAM registry hive, which contains local account credentials, to a file named sam on the C drive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the SAM hive to a file, which can be used to extract local account credentials.

attacks.description: This command attempts to find the string 'password' in configuration files within /etc/, potentially revealing credentials. It requires root privileges and is considered of medium safety risk due to its potential to reveal sensitive information.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output lines from files in /etc/ that contain the word 'password', which could include actual passwords or password hashes.

attacks.description: This command displays the contents of the shadow password file, which contains password hashes for users on the system. It does not require root privileges to list users but does to see password hashes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list user accounts and their corresponding password hashes if run with sufficient privileges, otherwise, it will only list users.

attacks.description: This command searches the bash history for lines containing 'sudo' and 'password', potentially revealing commands where passwords were entered in plain text.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output previous bash commands that contain both 'sudo' and 'password', which could indicate where passwords were used in commands.

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine, which can be used to discover network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the network configuration, including DNS and DHCP servers, which are network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network configuration information.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to filter and display only the running services, which can include network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the names of running services.

attacks.description: Display active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics
attacks.expected_behavior: Display a list of active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics

attacks.description: Scan for open ports and services on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Display a list of open ports and services on the local machine

attacks.description: Display information about sockets and network connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Display information about sockets and network connections

attacks.description: Archive a test file using Compress-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Create an archive of the test file

attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Encode the test file

attacks.description: Archive an encoded test file using Compress-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Create an archive of the encoded test file

attacks.description: Archive a single file using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a tar archive of the specified file

attacks.description: Archive multiple files using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a tar archive of the specified files

attacks.description: Archive a directory using zip
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a zip archive of the specified directory

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task that writes 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task using PowerShell that writes 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Open cron table for editing to add a new job
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open, allowing the user to add a new cron job.

attacks.description: Add a new cron job that runs a benign script daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be added to the user's cron table, scheduled to run the specified script daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Delete all cron jobs for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: All cron jobs for the current user will be deleted, which can impact scheduled tasks.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Input Capture'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300, 200); $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Enter your credentials:'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $form.Controls.Add($label); $textbox = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $textbox.Multiline = $true; $textbox.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(200, 100); $form.Controls.Add($textbox); $form.ShowDialog() | Out-Null; $textbox.Text | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\captured_input.txt'"
attacks.description: This command creates a simple form that prompts the user to enter their credentials and saves the input to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a form asking for user input and save the input to a file.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Enter your password: & set /p password= & echo %password% > %TEMP%\captured_password.txt"
attacks.description: This command prompts the user to enter their password and saves it to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user for a password and save it to a file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$wsh = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell; $wsh.Popup('Enter your credentials:', 0, 'Input Capture', 64) | Out-Null; $cred = $host.ui.prompt('Enter your credentials:', 'Input Capture'); $cred | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\captured_credentials.txt'"
attacks.description: This command uses the Windows Script Host to display a popup prompting the user to enter their credentials and saves the input to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a popup asking for user input and save the input to a file.

attacks.description: Simulate input capture by testing the mouse device
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will simulate mouse events and print them to the console, demonstrating how input can be captured or simulated.

attacks.description: Capture user input by recording the terminal session
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start recording the terminal session, capturing all user input until the session is ended, demonstrating how input can be captured.

attacks.description: Capture network input related to SSH connections
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture and display network traffic related to SSH connections, demonstrating how input can be captured from network activities, but requires admin privileges and poses a higher safety risk due to the potential for capturing sensitive information.

attacks.description: Simulate a local RDP connection to demonstrate the technique's basic usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection to the local machine via RDP, demonstrating the technique's basic application.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to get the process details of mstsc.exe, simulating an intermediate step in analyzing RDP activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves and displays information about the mstsc.exe process, demonstrating how one might inspect RDP-related processes.

attacks.description: Query the registry for RDP client settings, simulating an advanced step in analyzing RDP configurations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the registry settings related to the Terminal Server Client, showing how RDP configurations might be inspected.

attacks.description: Basic Remote Desktop Protocol connection using rdesktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a remote desktop connection to the specified IP address

attacks.description: Intermediate Remote Desktop Protocol connection with disk sharing using rdesktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a remote desktop connection with disk sharing to the specified IP address

attacks.description: Advanced Remote Desktop Protocol connection with disk sharing and custom resolution using rdesktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a remote desktop connection with disk sharing and custom resolution to the specified IP address

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be downloaded and executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Executes a malicious PowerShell script
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious PowerShell script will be executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Executes a malicious batch file
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious batch file will be executed, potentially causing harm to the system

attacks.description: Basic example of creating and executing a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious_file.txt in the /tmp directory and then attempts to execute it as a bash script.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of creating a malicious executable by copying a legitimate executable and making it executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the ls command to /tmp, makes it executable, and then runs it, demonstrating how a malicious executable could be created and executed.

attacks.description: Advanced example of creating and executing a malicious script with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script named malicious_payload.sh, makes it executable, and then attempts to execute it with sudo, simulating a scenario where a malicious script is run with elevated privileges.
